Content :

1Â Â Â - String Constructor
2Â Â Â - String Primitive.
3Â Â Â - String Object (String Object Wrapper).
4Â Â Â - Differance between String primitives and String objects
5Â Â Â - Compare in string
6Â Â Â - String Coercion (CÆ°Æ¡Ìƒng chÃªÌ chuÃ´Ìƒi)
7Â Â Â - Static Method
8Â Â Â - Instance Method.
9Â Â Â - Instance Properties.
10Â - .

GiÆ¡Ìi thiÃªÌ£u vÃªÌ€ String:âš“âš“âš“

- Trong Javascript, String ____ chuÃ´Ìƒi ____ caÌc vÄƒn baÌ‰n, string thuÃ´Ì£c nhoÌm kiÃªÌ‰u dÆ°Ìƒ liÃªÌ£u nguyÃªn thuÌ‰y (primitive).
- ReadOnly => Character access through built-in method or using Bracket Notation or charAt() - String trong Javascript laÌ€ kiÃªÌ‰u dÆ°Ìƒ liÃªÌ£u Case-sensitive , phÃ¢n biÃªÌ£t chÆ°Ìƒ hoa vaÌ€ chÆ°Ìƒ thÆ°Æ¡Ì€ng.

String Constructor :âš“âš“âš“

- The String constructor is used to create a new String Object (Which is not primitive). When called instead as a function, it performs type conversion to a Primitive String, which is usually more useful.
- String Constructor is only way for create instance of the 'class' String (an object wrapper)
- Note: String() can be called with or without new, but with different effects. See Return value.

String Primitive :âš“âš“âš“

- In Javascript String Primitive can be created by String Iteral or Function String. It is readOnly. It doesn't have any properties or methods of its own.
- When String is called as a function, Javascript implicit to create String Primitive. (It coerces the parameter to a String Primitive - Mozilla)
- String create from String literals (using double or single quotes) and string returned from Function String calls in a non-constructor context (that is, called without using the new keyword) are Primitive Strings. In contexts where a method is to be invoked on a Primitive String or a property lookup occurs, JavaScript will automatically wrap the string primitive and call the method or perform the property lookup on the wrapper object instead.

String Object :âš“âš“âš“

- A String object can always be converted to its primitive counterpart with the valueOf() method.
- String Primitive can use method and property of Object Wraper. In this case, Object Wraper of string primitive is Object String. When properties are accessed on primitives, JavaScript auto-boxes the value into a String Object and accesses the property on that String Object instead.

Differance between String primitives and String objects :


String Object Ä‘Æ°Æ¡Ì£c taÌ£o ra bÆ¡Ì‰i String Constructor
new String("example")

String Primitive Ä‘Æ°Æ¡Ì£c taÌ£o ra bÆ¡Ì‰i String iteral vaÌ€ String function 
const example1 = "example"
const example2 = String("example")
example1 === example2 //true

Method toString() - Method valueOf() :âš“âš“âš“

- Method toString() : This method built-in Object Wrapper return String Primitive, just like => String(ObjectWrapper.valueOf()).
- Method valueOf() : This method built-in Object Wrapper return itself Value. 

const example = "Example String"
example.toString() === example.valueOf() // it will be true
String(example).toString() === (new String(example)).valueOf() // it will be true


const exampleNumber = 999;
Number(exampleNumber).toString() === exampleNumber.toString(); return"999";
(new Number(exampleNumber)).toString() !== (new Number(exampleNumber)).valueOf(); "999" !== 999;
- toString() laÌ€ phÆ°Æ¡ng thÆ°Ìc built-in tÃ´Ì€n taÌ£i trong tÃ¢Ìt caÌ‰ Object Base, vaÌ€ Ä‘Æ°Æ¡Ì£c override laÌ£i Ä‘ÃªÌ‰ phuÌ€ hÆ¡Ì£p vÆ¡Ìi tÆ°Ì€ng kiÃªÌ‰u dÆ°Ìƒ liÃªÌ£u
- TaÌ£i sao method toString({}) laÌ£i return [object Object]
- TaÌ£i sao method valueOf({a: "example", b: 333}) laÌ£i return {a: "example", b: 333}

Compare Operators:âš“âš“âš“

- In C, the strcmp() function is used for comparing strings. In JavaScript, you just use the > , < , == , === Operators.
- Note that all comparison operators, example compare is strings case-sensitively. A common way to compare strings case-insensitively is to convert both to the same case (upper or lower) before comparing them.
- Method toUpperCase() and Method toLowerCase() will convert all characters in String to latin alphabet if it handles the conversion. 

"ÃŸÃŸÃŸ".touppercase() === "SSSSSS"; // Handle convert --> Convert Charactor into Latin Alphabet
"ÃŸÃŸÃŸ".tolowercase() === "ÃŸÃŸÃŸ"; // Do not handle convert --> No Convert
- KhiÌ sÆ°Ì‰ duÌ£ng caÌc pheÌp toaÌn so saÌnh trong Javascript, cÃ¢Ì€n lÆ°u yÌ 2 Ä‘iÃªÌ€u: - BiÃªÌ‰u thÆ°Ìc so saÌnh bÃªn traÌi coÌ cuÌ€ng kiÃªÌ‰u dÆ°Ìƒ liÃªÌ£u vÆ¡Ìi bÃªn phaÌ‰i:
- BiÃªÌ‰u thÆ°Ìc so saÌnh bÃªn traÌi khÃ´ng cuÌ€ng kiÃªÌ‰u dÆ°Ìƒ liÃªÌ£u vÆ¡Ìi bÃªn phaÌ‰i:
- NÃªÌu khÃ´ng thiÌ€ caÌ‰ biÃªÌ‰u thÆ°Ìc bÃªn traÌi vaÌ€ bÃªn phaÌ‰i seÌƒ cuÌ€ng Ä‘Æ°Æ¡Ì£c JS ngÃ¢Ì€m Ä‘iÌ£nh eÌp kiÃªÌ‰u vÃªÌ€ ngÆ°Ìƒ caÌ‰nh (non-numeric)
- numeric => Number(value) hoÄƒÌ£c Ä‘Æ¡n giaÌ‰n +value
Number(9_999) ; // number in mumeric = 999;
Number("9_999) ; // number string in numeric = 999;
Number("example") ; // string in numeric = NaN;
Number(null) ; // null primitive in numeric = 0;
Number(false) ; // false in numeric = 0; 
Number(true) ; // true in numeric = 1;
Number(undefined) ; // undefined in numeric = NaN
Number([1,1,1]) ; // Array > 2 element NaN
Number(["string","1"]) ; // Array > 2 element = NaN
Number(["string"]) ; // Array string = NaN;
Number(["111"]) ; // Array only 1 element type number string or number inside = 111
Number({}) ; // object in numeric = NaN 
Number({"1":1}) ; // object in numeric = NaN
Number(Symbol("1")) ; // Uncaught TypeError: Cannot convert a Symbol value to a number

String to Another Comparison

 - The operands are compared using the comparison algorithm.
- String to string comparison
 - If both values are strings, they are compared as strings, based on the values of the Unicode code points they contain.
- String to another comparison
 - Otherwise JavaScript attempts to convert non-numeric types to numeric values.
- Strings are converted based on the values they contain, and are converted as NaN if they do not contain numeric values.
- Read More at: Javascript.info

String Coercions:

- Explicit : TÆ°Æ¡Ì€ng minh
- Implicit : NgÃ¢Ì€m Ä‘iÌ£nh 

const nullVar = null  
nullVar.toString() // TypeError: nullVar is null 
String(nullVar) // return 'null' 

const undefinedVar = undefined 
undefinedVar.toString() // TypeError: undefinedVar is  // null 
String(undefinedVar) // return 'null'

Yeild :

# sec-string-objects

Related Sections

Involved :

Static properties:

- PhÃ¢n biÃªÌ£t biÃªÌn vaÌ€ haÌ€m cuÌ‰a class vaÌ€ biÃªÌn vaÌ€ haÌ€m cuÌ‰a Ä‘Ã´Ìi tÆ°Æ¡Ì£ng thuÃ´Ì£c class

UTF-8 Miscellaneous Symbols

- SÆ°Ì‰ duÌ£ng Icon as String

Primitive.

- In JavaScript, a primitive (primitive value, primitive data type) is data that is not an object and has no methods or properties. There are 7 primitive data types:
Â Â  - string
Â Â  - number
Â Â  - bigint
Â Â  - boolean
Â Â  - undefined
Â Â  - symbol
Â Â  - null
- All primitives are immutable, cannot be altered. Primitive is readOnly has no method, no property
- ÄÆ°Ì€ng nhÃ¢Ì€m lÃ¢Ìƒn giÆ°Ìƒa mÃ´Ì£t giaÌ triÌ£ nguyÃªn thuÌ‰y "primitive" vaÌ€ mÃ´Ì£t biÃªÌn Ä‘Æ°Æ¡Ì£c gaÌn giaÌ triÌ£ nguyÃªn thuÌ‰y
- When properties are accessed on primitives, JavaScript auto-boxes the value into a wrapper object and accesses the property on that object instead.
- Khi caÌc thuÃ´Ì£c tiÌnh Ä‘Æ°Æ¡Ì£c tuy cÃ¢Ì£p trÃªn caÌc primitives, Javascript seÌƒ tÆ°Ì£ Ä‘Ã´Ì£ng xem primitive laÌ€ Ä‘Ã´Ìi sÃ´Ì cuÌ‰a Object Wrapper vaÌ€ truy cÃ¢Ì£p caÌc thuÃ´Ì£c tiÌnh trÃªn object Ä‘oÌ. MÃ´Ìƒi primitive seÌƒ coÌ Object Wrapper khaÌc nhau. ViÌ duÌ£ : new String("abc") !== new String("abc"), Tuy kÃªÌt quaÌ‰ ra false nhÆ°ng chuÌng laÌ£i coÌ chung mÃ´Ì£t Base Ä‘oÌ laÌ€ Object String.

methodHelper.syntax:
Syntax: StringPrimitive.length

 

const example = "Example String"
example.length === 14 // return number 14

const emoji = "ğŸ˜„";
emoji.length === 2 // return number 2 cause ğŸ˜„ is not UTF-16
emoji.lenght !== [...emoji].length  // false -> 2 !== 1
methodHelper.equal:
const example = "Example String"
example.length === 14 // return number 14
const newArray = [...example] // spread syntax 
newArray.length === 14 // return number 14
see bellow: Spread syntax
methodHelper.description:
Syntax: StringPrimitive.length

 - The length read-only property of a string contains the length of the string in UTF-16 code units. Length laÌ€ thuÃ´Ì£c tiÌnh chiÌ‰ Ä‘oÌ£c thÃªÌ‰ hiÃªÌ£n chuÃ´Ìƒi Æ¡Ì‰ Ä‘Æ¡n viÌ£ maÌƒ UTF-16. ChiÌ‰ Ä‘oÌ£c tÆ°Ìc laÌ€ chuÌng ta vÃ¢Ìƒn coÌ thÃªÌ‰ truy cÃ¢Ì£p tuy nhiÃªn khÃ´ng sÆ°Ì‰a xoÌa Ä‘Æ°Æ¡Ì£c.
- Writable : no
- Enumerable : no
- Configurable : no
- The number of elements in the String value represented by this String object. Once a String object is initialized, this property is unchanging. It has the attributes { [[Writable]]: false, [[Enumerable]]: false, [[Configurable]]: false }.
. Throw error in strict mode if override length. 

const myString = "bluebells"; 
myString.length === 9 // before try to overide length
myString.length = 4; // try to overide length => fail 
myString.length === 9 // still return number 9 "bluebells".length

ÄÄƒÌ£c taÌ‰ : ECMA

methodHelper.syntax:
Syntax: StringPrimitive.[Symbol.iterator]()

 

string[Symbol.iterator]() // Syntax create iterator object in string

const example = 'Example String';
const iterator = example[Symbol.iterator]();
let theChar = iterator.next();

while (!theChar.done && theChar.value !== ' ') {
  console.log(theChar.value);
  theChar = iterator.next();
}
LiÃªn quan:
- iterable protocol : Giao thÆ°Ìc lÄƒÌ£p
- @@iterator method makes strings iterable : CoÌ thÃªÌ‰ lÄƒÌ£p
- Iteration Protocol : There are two protocols: The iterable protocol and the iterator protocol.
LÆ¡Ì£i iÌch cuÌ‰a:
- @@iterator laÌ€ method thÆ°Ì£c thi iterable protocol (giao thÆ°Ìc lÄƒÌ£p) giuÌp cho caÌc Ä‘Ã´Ìi tÆ°Æ¡Ì£ng coÌ method @@iterator Ä‘ÃªÌ€u coÌ thÃªÌ‰ lÄƒÌ£p - iterable => coÌ thÃªÌ‰ lÄƒÌ£p bÄƒÌ€ng for...of ... coÌ€n for...in, fori vaÌ€ method forEach thiÌ€ sao ????

Syntax: StringPrimitive.[Symbol.iterator]()

 - 1. iterable protocol.
- 2. iterable.
- String.prototype[@@iterator]() :
There are two protocols: The iterable protocol and the iterator protocol.

ÄÄƒÌ£c taÌ‰ : ECMA

methodHelper.syntax:
Syntax: StringPrimitive.valueOf()

 

// Overriding valueOf for custom objects by function and prototype
function myDataType(n) {
  this[ "[[primitive]]" ]= n;
}
myDataType.prototype.valueOf = function() {
  return this[ "[[primitive]]" ];
};

const myObject1 = new myDataType(4);
myObject1.valueOf(); // number 4
const myObject2 = new myDataType( {a :1 ,b:2 ,c: {d:1,e:2} } );
myObject2.valueOf() ; // {a :1 ,b:2 ,c: {d:1,e:2} } 
const myObject3 = {a :1 ,b:2 ,c: {d:1,e:2} } ;
myObject3.valueOf() ; // {a :1 ,b:2 ,c: {d:1,e:2} } 
myObject2.valueOf() === myObject3.valueOf() // false

// Overriding valueOf for custom objects 
class Box {
  #value;
  constructor(value) {this.#value = value; }
  valueOf() { return this.#value;}
}

const box = new Box(123);
console.log(box + 456); // 579
console.log(box == 123); // true
box.valueOf();
methodHelper.equal:
- Method ValueOf() return itself differance with method toString() 

const  Arr = [1,2,3];
const object = {a :1 ,b:2 ,c: {d:1,e:2} }

// example with method valueOf
Number(3).valueOf() === Number(3); //  === 3
String("example").valueOf() === String("example"); // === "example"
String("3").valueOf() !== Number(3); // "3" !== 3 
Number(3).valueOf() !== String(3); // 3 !== "3"
Boolean("false").valueOf() === Boolean("false"); // true === true
Arr.valueOf() === Arr; // ArrId = ArrId
object.valueOf() === object; //objId === objId

// example with method toString
Number(3).toString() === "3" // String(3)
Number("3").toString() === "3" // String(3)
String("example").toString() === "example" // String("example")
Boolean(true).toString() === "true" // String(true)
Boolean(false).toString() === "false" // String(false)
Arr.toString() === '1,2,3'
object.toString() === '[object Object]'
methodHelper.description:
Syntax: StringPrimitive.valueOf()

 - Method valueOf() same with method toString() in String Object, Both return String Primitive.
- The method valueOf() method returns the [[primitive]] properties of Object Wrapper.
- 1. BigInt.valueOf()
- 2. Boolean.valueOf()
- 3. Number.valueOf()
- 4. String.valueOf()
- 5. Object.valueOf()
- 6. Symbol.valueOf()
- 7. Date.valueOf()

ÄÄƒÌ£c taÌ‰ : ECMA

methodHelper.syntax:
Syntax: StringPrimitive.toString()

 

const example = "Example String" 
const emoji = "ğŸ˜„";

example.toString() === "Example String" // equal with example.valueOf() === example.toString()
emoji.toString() === emoji // true "ğŸ˜„" === "ğŸ˜„"
methodHelper.equal:
// example with method toString
const  Arr = [1,2,3];
const object = {a :1 ,b:2 ,c: {d:1,e:2} }

Number(3).toString() === "3" // String(3)
Number("3").toString() === "3" // String(3)
String("example").toString() === "example" // String("example")
Boolean(true).toString() === "true" // String(true)
Boolean(false).toString() === "false" // String(false)
Arr.toString() === '1,2,3'
object.toString() === '[object Object]'
methodHelper.description:
Syntax: StringPrimitive.toString()

 - 1. Array.toString
- 2. BigInt.toString
- 3. Boolean.toString
- 4. Date.toString
- 5. Error.toString
- 6. Function.toString
- 7. Number.toString
- 8. Object.toString
- 9. RegExp.toString
- 10. String.toString
- 11. Symbol.toString
- 12. TypedArray.toString
LÆ°u yÌ:
- ({a: "example", b:1 }).toString() === '[object Object]'
- [1,2,3].toString() === '1,2,3'

ÄÄƒÌ£c taÌ‰ : ECMA

methodHelper.method:
Access character in string

1 - Square Bracket Notation

2 - String.prototype.at()

3 - String.prototype.charAt()
methodHelper.syntax:
Access character in string

1 - Square Bracket Notation


// Access by Square Bracket Notation => StringPrimitive[characterIndex]
const exampleString = "Example string"

exampleString[-exampleString.length -10] === undefined
exampleString[-exampleString.length] === undefined
exampleString[-exampleString.length + 1] === undefined
exampleString[-1] === undefined
exampleString[0] === "E" // fristCharacter
exampleString[exampleString.length - 1] === "g" // lastCharacter
exampleString[exampleString.length] === undefined
exampleString[exampleString.length +10] === undefined
exampleString["string"] === undefined
exampleString[undefined] === undefined
exampleString[null] === undefined
exampleString[NaN] === undefined

2 - String.prototype.at()


const exampleString = "Example string"

exampleString.at(-exampleString.length -10) === undefined 
exampleString.at(-exampleString.length) === "E"
exampleString.at(-exampleString.length + 1) === "x"
exampleString.at(-1) === "g"
exampleString.at(0) === "E" // fristCharacter
exampleString.at(exampleString.length - 1) === "g" // lastCharacter
exampleString.at(exampleString.length) === undefined
exampleString.at(exampleString.length +10) === undefined
exampleString.at("string") === exampleString.at(0) // "E"
exampleString.at(undefined) === exampleString.at(0) // "E"
exampleString.at(null) ===  exampleString.at(0) // "E"
exampleString.at(NaN) ===  exampleString.at(0) // "E"

3 - String.prototype.charAt()


const exampleString = "Example string"

exampleString.charAt(-exampleString.length -10) === ""
exampleString.charAt(-exampleString.length) === ""
exampleString.charAt(-exampleString.length + 1) === ""
exampleString.charAt(-1) === ""
exampleString.charAt(0) === "E"
exampleString.charAt(exampleString.length - 1) === "g"
exampleString.charAt(exampleString.length) === ""
exampleString.charAt(exampleString.length +10) === ""
exampleString.charAt("string") === exampleString.charAt(0) // "E"
exampleString.charAt(undefined) === exampleString.charAt(0) // "E"
exampleString.charAt(null) ===  exampleString.charAt(0) // "E"
exampleString.charAt(NaN) ===  exampleString.at(0) // "E"
methodHelper.equal:
Access character in string

1 - Square Bracket Notation


// Access by Square Bracket Notation => StringPrimitive[characterIndex]
if(characterIndex === "numeric" ){
  characterIndex in [0;length) ? return StringPrimitive[characterIndex] : return undefined 
}else{
  return undefined
}

const example = "Example String"

2 - String.prototype.at()


// Syntax StringPrimitive.at(characterIndex)
if(characterIndex === "numeric" ){
  characterIndex in [-length;length) ? return StringPrimitive.at(characterIndex) : return undefined 
}else{
  return StringPrimitive.at(0)
}

3 - String.prototype.charAt()


// Syntax StringPrimitive.charAt(characterIndex)
if(characterIndex === "numeric" ){
  characterIndex in [0;length) ? return StringPrimitive.charAt(characterIndex) : return "" // empty-string
}else{
  return StringPrimitive.charAt(0)
}

methodHelper.syntax:
1 - StringPrimitive.indexOf(searchString, position)

2 - StringPrimitive.lastIndexOf(searchString, position)

 

// Syntax : StringPrimitive.indexOf(searchString, position = 0)
// Syntax : StringPrimitive.lastIndexOf(searchString, position = 0) , using same algorithm with indexOf
const exampleString = "Example string 123 NaN null undefined"

exampleString.indexOf("xample") === 1
exampleString.indexOf("AnotherString") === -1 // do not exits on exampleString
exampleString.indexOf(1) === 15 // searchString will be impicit to String => exampleString.indexOf("1")
exampleString.indexOf([1,2,3]) === 15 // searchString will be impicit to String => exampleString.indexOf("1,2,3")
exampleString.indexOf(undefined) === 28 // searchString will be impicit to String => exampleString.indexOf("undefined")
exampleString.indexOf(null) === 23 // searchString will be impicit to String => exampleString.indexOf("null")
exampleString.indexOf(NaN) === 19 // searchString will be impicit to String => exampleString.indexOf("NaN")

// example with position
"0123456".indexOf("3",-99) === 3 // "0123456".indexOf("3",0)
"0123456".indexOf("3",-1) === 3 // "0123456".indexOf("3",0)
"0123456".indexOf("3",0) === 3 //"0123456".indexOf("3")
"0123456".indexOf("3",1) === 3
"0123456".indexOf("3",2) === 3
"0123456".indexOf("3",3) === 3
"0123456".indexOf("3",99) === -1
methodHelper.equal:
1 - indexOf

2 - lastIndexOf

 

// Syntax : StringPrimitive.indexOf(searchString, position = 0)
1 - searchString algorithm;
if(typeof searchString !== string){
 searchString = String(searchString) // Javascript implicit searchString to String
}
StringPrimitive.indexOf(searchString, position = 0)

2 - position algorithm;
if(position < 0){
    StringPrimitive.indexOf(searchString, 0) // return index base-on StringPrimitive or -1
  } else if(0 < position < length){
    StringPrimitive.indexOf(searchString, position) // return index base-on StringPrimitive or -1
  }else{return -1  // do not search }
}
methodHelper.description:
1 - StringPrimitive.indexOf(searchString, position)

2 - StringPrimitive.lastIndexOf(searchString, position)

 

// Syntax : StringPrimitive.indexOf(searchString, position = 0)
1 - searchString algorithm;
if(typeof searchString !== string){
 searchString = String(searchString) // Javascript implicit searchString to String
}
StringPrimitive.indexOf(searchString, position = 0)

2 - position algorithm;
if(position < 0){
    StringPrimitive.indexOf(searchString, 0) // return index base-on StringPrimitive or -1
  } else if(0 < position < length){
    StringPrimitive.indexOf(searchString, position) // return index base-on StringPrimitive or -1
  }else{return -1  // do not search }
}

ÄÄƒÌ£c taÌ‰ : ECMA IndexOf

methodHelper.method:
Remove white-space

1 - String.prototype.trim()


2 - String.prototype.trimEnd()


3 - String.prototype.trimStart()
methodHelper.syntax:
Remove white-space


1 - StringPrimitive.trim()


// Syntax StringPrimitive.trim()
const example = "   Example String   "
example.trim() === "Example String"

2 - StringPrimitive.trimEnd()


// Syntax StringPrimitive.trimEnd()
const example = "   Example String   "
example.trimEnd() === "   Example String"

3 - StringPrimitive.trimStart()


// Syntax StringPrimitive.trimStart()
const example = "   Example String   "
example.trimStart() === "Example String   "
methodHelper.description:
1 - StringPrimitive.trim()

- The trim() method removes whitespace from both ends of a string and returns a new string, without modifying the original string. Whitespace in this context is all the whitespace characters (space, tab, no-break space, etc.)
- If neither the beginning or end of str has any whitespace, a new string is still returned (essentially a copy of str), with no exception being thrown.

2 - StringPrimitive.trimEnd()

- The trimStart() method removes whitespace from the end of a string.
- If the end of str has no whitespace, a new string is still returned.

3 - StringPrimitive.trimStart()

- The trimStart() method removes whitespace from the beginning of a string.
- If the end of str has no whitespace, a new string is still returned.

ÄÄƒÌ£c taÌ‰ : ECMA Trim

ÄÄƒÌ£c taÌ‰ : ECMA TrimStart

ÄÄƒÌ£c taÌ‰ : ECMA TrimEnd

methodHelper.syntax:
StringPrimitive.split(separator, limit = undefined)

separator : can be a string or regular expression
limit : a non-negative-number (limit >= 0) , limit is a number of elements outputs. limite is in numeric/ number conversion. Javascript Implicit limit to number 

const example = "Example String"
example.split()  // output === ['Example String']
example.split("") // output === ['E', 'x', 'a', 'm', ..., 'n', 'g']
example.split("", undefined) // output === example.split()
example.split("", 4) // output === ['E', 'x', 'a', 'm']
example.split(" ") // output === ['Example', 'String']
example.split(" ", 0) // output === []
example.split(" ", 1) // output === ['Example']
example.split(" ", 99) // output === ['Example', 'String']
example.split(" ", -99) // output === ['Example', 'String']
example.split(" ", NaN) // output === []
example.split(" ", null) // output === []
example.split(" ", false) // output === []
example.split(" ", true) // output === ['Example']
methodHelper.equal:

Number(["string","1"]) ; // Array > 2 element = NaN

methodHelper.description:
StringPrimitive.split(separator, limit = undefined)

- Method split into array, PhÆ°Æ¡ng thÆ°Ìc slit ("taÌch ra") traÌ‰ vÃªÌ€ mÃ´Ì£t chuÃ´Ìƒi
- The split() method takes a pattern and divides a String into an ordered list of substrings by searching for the pattern, puts these substrings into an array, and returns the array of string.
- PhÆ°Æ¡ng thÆ°Ìc split nhÃ¢Ì£n vaÌ€o mÃ´Ì£t pattern, dÆ°Ì£a vaÌ€o Ä‘oÌ noÌ chia nhoÌ‰ chuÃ´Ìƒi ra thaÌ€nh mÃ´Ì£t danh saÌch caÌc chuÃ´Ìƒi con theo thÆ°Ì tÆ°Ì£, boÌ‰ chuÌng vaÌ€ mÃ´Ì£t chuÃ´Ìƒi vaÌ€ traÌ‰ vÃªÌ€ mÃ´Ì£t array
- Litmit paramater in numeric conversion (Javascript will implicit argument into number)
- Litmit === undefined || litmit < 0 ? split(separator) : split(separator, Number(limit) )
- Number(limit) = 0 ? return empty array : return array contain less than or equal element than limit

ÄÄƒÌ£c taÌ‰ : ECMA

methodHelper.syntax:
Syntax: StringPrimitive.slice(indexStart, indexEnd)

 

const example = "Example String" // example.length === 14

// 1- just indexStart, omit indexEnd
example.slice(-99) === 'Example String'
example.slice(-14) === 'Example String'
example.slice(-1) === 'g' // lastCharacter in example
example.slice(0) === 'Example String'
example.slice(1) === 'xample String'
example.slice(14) === ''
example.slice(99) === ''

example.slice(NaN) === "Example String" // indexStart convert into numeric === NaN => indexStart = 0
example.slice(null) === "Example String" // indexStart convert into numeric === 0 ==> indexStart = 0
example.slice(undefined) === "Example String" // indexStart convert into numeric === NaN => indexStart = 0
example.slice([]) === example.slice(0) // indexStart convert into numeric === 0 ==> indexStart = 0
example.slice([0]) === example.slice(0) // indexStart convert into numeric === 0 ==> indexStart = 0
example.slice([1,2,3]) === example.slice(NaN) // indexStart convert into numeric === NaN ==> indexStart = 0

// 2 - both indexStart and indexEnd 
// indexStart < 0 ? indexStart = max(length + indexStart, 0) : indexStart = max(indexStart, length)
// indexEnd < 0 ? indexEnd = max(length + indexEnd, 0) : indexEnd  = min(indexEnd, length)

example.slice(-99,-99) === example.slice(0,0) // output : ""
example.slice(-14,-14) === example.slice(0,0) // output : ""
example.slice(-1,-1) === example.slice(1,1)  // output : ""
example.slice(33,-1) === example.slice(14,13) // output : ""

Number("Example String") === NaN // noticed: NaN !== NaN
Number(NaN) === NaN // noticed: NaN !== NaN
Number(undefined) === NaN // noticed: NaN !== NaN
methodHelper.description:
StringPrimitive.split(separator, limit = undefined)

- The slice() method get a part of string returns it as a new string, without modifying the original string. 

StringPrimitive.slice(indexStart , indexEnd = length)
//case 1 : non-numeric => JavaScript implicit into numeric:
- indexStart === NaN => indexStart = 0 
- indexEnd === NaN => indexEnd = length

//case 2 : numeric
indexStart < 0 ? indexStart = max(length + indexStart, 0) : indexStart = max(indexStart, length)
indexEnd < 0 ? indexEnd = max(length + indexEnd, 0) : indexEnd  = min(indexEnd, length)

> If from â‰¥ to, return the empty String.
> Return the substring of S from from to to.

ÄÄƒÌ£c taÌ‰ : ECMA

methodHelper.syntax:
StringPrimitive.startsWith(searchString, position = 0) 


const example = "Example String" // example.length === 14

example.startWith("E") === true
example.slice("Example") === "Example String"
example.slice("Example", -99) === "Example String" // position is numeric < 0 => max(-99 ,0) => example.slice("Example", 0)
example.slice("Example", -1) === "Example String" // position is numeric < 0 => max(-99 ,0) => example.slice("Example", 0)
example.slice("Example", 0) === "Example String" // default
example.slice("Example", 1) === "xample String" // position is numeric > 0 => min(1, length = 14) => example.slice("Example", 1)
example.slice("Example", 14) === "xample String" // position is numeric > 0 => min(14, length = 14) => example.slice("Example", 14)
example.slice("Example", 99) === "Example String" // position is numeric > 0 => min(99, length = 14) => example.slice("Example", 14)

Number(undefined) === NaN // noticed: NaN !== NaN
methodHelper.description:
StringPrimitive.startsWith(searchString, position = 0)

- Method startsWith is case-sensitive determines "xaÌc Ä‘iÌ£nh" whether StringPrimitive begins with the characters of a specified string return true/ false.
- If searchString is a regex will be TypeError 

// Syntax : StringPrimitive.startsWith(searchString, position = 0)
1 - searchString algorithm;
if( SearchString is RegularExpress ) TypeError
else convert SearchString into String(SearchString);

2 - position algorithm;
if ( position is non-numeric ) Number(position) === NaN | 0 => return new position = 0 
else ( position is numeric ) 
=> if ( position <= 0 ) position = 0
=> if ( position > 0 ) position = position
=> if ( position > length ) return false
- SearchString is String Conversion => Javascript implicit SearchString into String first before process => String(searchString)

ÄÄƒÌ£c taÌ‰ : ECMA

methodHelper.method:
String.prototype.includes()
Ä‘ang sai => Ä‘uÌng =>
position >= length return false
methodHelper.syntax:
Syntax: StringPrimitive.includes(searchString, position = undefined)

 

const example = "Example String" // example.length === 14

example.includes("String") === true
example.includes("String", -99) === true // position is numeric < 0 => max(-99, 0) => example.includes("Example", 0)
example.includes("String", -14) === true // position is numeric < 0 => max(-14, 0) => example.includes("Example", 0)
example.includes("String", -1) === true // position is numeric < 0 => max(-1, 0) => example.includes("Example", 0)
example.includes("String", 0) === true // default
example.includes("xample", 1) === true // position is numeric > 0 => min(1, length = 14) => example.includes("xample", 1)
example.includes("g", 13) === true // position is numeric > 0 => min(1, length = 14) => example.includes("xample", 1)
example.includes("g", 14) === false // position is numeric > 0 && position >= length => return false
example.includes("g", 99) === false // position is numeric > 0 && position >= length => return false


example.includes("Example", undefined) === example.includes("Example", 0) // position convert into numeric = NaN => position = 0
example.includes("Example", NaN) === example.includes("Example", 0) // position convert into numeric = NaN => position = 0 
example.includes("Example", null) === example.includes("Example", 0) // position convert into numeric = 0 => position = 0
example.includes("Example", {}) === example.includes("Example", 0) // position convert into numeric = NaN => position = 0
example.includes("Example", []) === example.includes("Example", 0) // position convert into numeric = 0 => position = 0
example.includes("Example", [1,2,3]) === example.includes("Example", 0) // position convert into numeric = NaN => position = 0
example.includes("Example", false) === example.includes("Example", 0) // position convert into numeric = 0 => position = 0
example.includes("Example", true) === example.includes("Example", 1) // position convert into numeric = 1 => position = 1
methodHelper.equal:
Syntax: StringPrimitive.includes(searchString, position)
- String conversion : String conversion Ä‘Æ°Æ¡Ì£c aÌp duÌ£ng vÆ¡Ìi searchString
- Number Conversion : Numeric conversion Ä‘Æ°Æ¡Ì£c aÌp duÌ£ng vÆ¡Ìi position
-PhÆ°Æ¡ng thÆ°Ìc include sÆ°Ì‰ duÌ£ng phÆ°Æ¡ng thÆ°Ìc indexOf

else convert SearchString into String(SearchString);

2 - position algorithm;

else ( position is numeric ) 
=> if ( position <= 0 ) position = 0
=> if ( position > 0 ) position = position
=> if ( position >= length ) return false

methodHelper.syntax:
Syntax : StringPrimitive.toLowerCase() | StringPrimitive.toLocaleLowerCase()

Syntax : StringPrimitive.toUpperCase() | StringPrimitive.toLocaleUpperCase()

1 - StringPrimitive.toLowerCase()



const example = "Example STRING"
example.toLowerCase = "example string"

2 - StringPrimitive.toLocaleLowerCase(locoles)



const example = "Example STRING"
example.toLocaleLowerCase= "example string"
[later]

3 - StringPrimitive.toUpperCase()



const example = "Example STRING"
example.toUpperCase= "EXAMPLE STRING"

4 - StringPrimitive.toLocaleUpperCase(locoles)



const example = "Example STRING"
example.toLocaleUpperCase= "EXAMPLE STRING"

[later]
methodHelper.description:
1 - StringPrimitive.toLowerCase()


- Method toLowerCase return the value of the string converted to lower case. toLowerCase() doesn't modify the original string.

2 - StringPrimitive.toLocaleLowerCase(locales)


- Method toLocaleLowerCase return the value of the string converted to lower case. toLocaleLowerCase() doesn't modify the original string.
- Some locales, such as Turkish, whose case mappings do not follow the default case mappings in Unicode, there may be a different result with method toLowerCase.

3 - StringPrimitive.toUpperCase()


- Method toUpperCase return the value of the string converted to lower case. toUpperCase() doesn't modify the original string
- TypeError When called on null or undefined.
- Example : String.prototype.toUpperCase.call(undefined)

4 - StringPrimitive.toLocaleUpperCase()


- Method toLocaleUpperCase return the value of the string converted to lower case. toLocaleUpperCase() doesn't modify the original string

ÄÄƒÌ£c taÌ‰ : ECMA ToLowerCase

ÄÄƒÌ£c taÌ‰ : ECMA toLocaleLowerCase
